interestingcomments.content: Blower, if that fails, silicone stamp, if still dirty wet clean. So how do you clean it when it gets dirty?
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Blower, if that fails, silicone stamp, if still dirty wet clean. So how do you clean it when it gets dirty?

interestingcomments.content: It could be air bubbles on the film before the initial agitation. Tap the tank hard after filling. You think so? The white spots on the positive are black spots on the negative, so these are overdeveloped spots, isn’t it?
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: It could be air bubbles on the film before the initial agitation. Tap the tank hard after filling. You think so? The white spots on the positive are black spots on the negative, so these are overdeveloped spots, isn’t it?

interestingcomments.content: Perhaps a silly question, but have you cleaned the sensor, it looks somewhat dirty? Could the spot be some gunk on it?
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Perhaps a silly question, but have you cleaned the sensor, it looks somewhat dirty? Could the spot be some gunk on it?

interestingcomments.content: Chris, there are no silvered surfaces in VIOOH, light is reflected within the prism though. I believe this is because of different "thickness" of glas and air, it is along time ago when I learned it at school:-) I believe this is dust/dirt and could be cleaned, see pdf in one of the postings above how to do it. So, if there are no silverings on the prism, what is the risc of cleaning then?

interestingcomments.content: Hello All, I have repeatedly cleaned the sensor in my M8, cant say that i would actually consider this dust but some purplish/white specs remain on my sensor. Does not want to come off using rocket blower and Visible Dust Plus. In previous cleanings done with eyelead gel stick. Thoughts? Steve
